A **dwarvish mithril-coat** is a type of [body armor](/wiki/Body_armor "Body armor") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. It is made of [mithril](/wiki/Mithril "Mithril").

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Description](#Description)

- [3 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [4 History](#History)

- [5 Variants](#Variants)

  - [5.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)
  - [5.2 UnNetHack](#UnNetHack)
  - [5.3 dNetHack](#dNetHack)
  - [5.4 xNetHack](#xNetHack)
  - [5.5 SpliceHack](#SpliceHack)
  - [5.6 EvilHack](#EvilHack)
  - [5.7 Hack'EM](#Hack.27EM)

- [6 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)

- [7 References](#References)

## Generation

In addition to random generation, armor [shops](/wiki/Shop "Shop") and general stores can stock dwarvish mithril-coats.

Live [dwarves](/wiki/Dwarf_\(monster_attribute\) "Dwarf (monster attribute)") that [are generated with](/wiki/Monster_starting_inventory "Monster starting inventory") a [dwarvish short sword](/wiki/Dwarvish_short_sword "Dwarvish short sword") and [dwarvish iron helm](/wiki/Dwarvish_iron_helm "Dwarvish iron helm") have a 1⁄3 chance of generating with a dwarvish mithril-coat.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

[Player monster](/wiki/Player_monster "Player monster") [barbarians](/wiki/Barbarian_\(player_monster\) "Barbarian (player monster)"), [knights](/wiki/Knight_\(player_monster\) "Knight (player monster)"), [priests](/wiki/Priest_\(player_monster\) "Priest (player monster)"), and [valkyries](/wiki/Valkyrie_\(player_monster\) "Valkyrie (player monster)") have an effective 1⁄62 chance (roughly \~1.61%) of forcing a dwarvish mithril-coat in place of their initial body armor.[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)[\[3\]](#cite_note-3)[\[4\]](#cite_note-4)[\[5\]](#cite_note-5)

## Description

When worn, a dwarvish mithril-coat confers 6 base [AC](/wiki/AC "AC") and [MC2](/wiki/MC2 "MC2") and hinders [spellcasting](/wiki/Spellcasting "Spellcasting"). Wearing or removing a dwarvish mithril-coat takes only 1 turn.[\[6\]](#cite_note-6)

## Strategy

Dwarvish-mithril coats are among the best available body armor after [dragon scale mail](/wiki/Dragon_scale_mail "Dragon scale mail") - obtaining one is often a major goal for early game characters due to its high AC and low weight, and it often provides as much AC as the rest of their armor combined. The low weight is also ideal for early characters with low [strength](/wiki/Strength "Strength") and no [bag of holding](/wiki/Bag_of_holding "Bag of holding"). Even characters in spellcasting roles (such as [Wizards](/wiki/Wizard "Wizard")) will occasionally make use of a mithril-coat to boost AC, only removing it to cast as needed. The dwarvish mithril-coat has one more point of base AC than an [elven mithril-coat](/wiki/Elven_mithril-coat "Elven mithril-coat"), though the elven coat can be enchanted safely from +5 unlike non-elven armor.

Barring a [wish](/wiki/Wish "Wish"), a dwarvish mithril-coat can easily last as a character's primary armor throughout the mid-game or until their desired set of dragon scales becomes available, whichever occurs first. The coat's material protects it from erosion, though it will still break if a [polymorph trap](/wiki/Polymorph_trap "Polymorph trap") turns you into a large enough monster - both this and the general tendency to swap to dragon scale mail often deters players from using any [scroll of enchant armor](/wiki/Scroll_of_enchant_armor "Scroll of enchant armor") on it.

## History

The dwarvish mithril-coat first appears in [NetHack 3.0.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.0 "NetHack 3.0.0"). From this version to [NetHack 3.4.3](/wiki/NetHack_3.4.3 "NetHack 3.4.3"), including variants based on those versions, the dwarvish mithril-coat grants [MC3](/wiki/Magic_cancellation_\(3.4.3\) "Magic cancellation (3.4.3)").

## Variants

Variants based on NetHack 3.4.3 and earlier versions may retain the MC3 granted by wearing a dwarvish mithril-coat, while variants that employ [object materials](/wiki/Object_materials "Object materials") may replace the dwarvish mithril-coat with a similar item that can be made of mithril.

Some variants may give dwarves an AC bonus for wearing a dwarvish mithril-coat or equivalent armor, including [dwarven](/wiki/Dwarf_\(starting_race\) "Dwarf (starting race)") player characters.

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), the dwarvish mithril-coat grants MC3 while worn, and the functionally-identical [dark elven mithril-coat](/wiki/Dark_elven_mithril-coat "Dark elven mithril-coat") is introduced.

### UnNetHack

In [UnNetHack](/wiki/UnNetHack "UnNetHack"), the dwarvish mithril-coat grants a +1 AC bonus to dwarves that wear them, including player dwarves.

Several dwarvish mithril-coats can be found in the [Ruins of Moria](/wiki/Ruins_of_Moria "Ruins of Moria") branch: 2-4 cursed mithril-coats are generated buried around the second floor at level creation, and 2-8 blessed and positively-enchanted mithril-coats are generated scattered around the fourth floor at level creation.

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack"), the dwarvish mithril-coat grants 3 AC, 3 [DR](/wiki/DR "DR") and MC3 when worn - its weight is lowered to 40 aum, the same as dragon scale mail in *NetHack*.

[The Armor of Khazad-dum](/wiki/DNetHack_artifacts#The_Armor_of_Khazad-dum "DNetHack artifacts") is a lawful, intelligent [artifact](/wiki/Artifact "Artifact") dwarvish mithril-coat that is the first [sacrifice gift](/wiki/Sacrifice_gift "Sacrifice gift") for dwarf [Nobles](/wiki/Noble "Noble") and favors them. It grants [magic resistance](/wiki/Magic_resistance "Magic resistance") and +4 AC while worn, and can be enchanted to +7.

### xNetHack

In [xNetHack](/wiki/XNetHack "XNetHack"), dwarvish mithril-coats are replaced with [dwarvish ring mail](/wiki/Dwarvish_ring_mail "Dwarvish ring mail"), which has a base material of [iron](/wiki/Iron "Iron") and grants 4 base AC - a mithril set of dwarven ring mail behaves identically to a dwarven mithril-coat, since mithril body armor will always grant at least MC2. [Dwarf leaders](/wiki/Dwarf_leader "Dwarf leader") and [dwarf rulers](/wiki/Dwarf_ruler "Dwarf ruler") that generate with dwarvish ring mail have an increased chance of it being made of mithril.

### SpliceHack

In [SpliceHack](/wiki/SpliceHack "SpliceHack"), dwarvish mithril-coats are also replaced with dwarvish ring mail, similar to xNetHack.

### EvilHack

In [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"), dwarvish mithril-coats are replaced with [dwarvish chain mail](/wiki/Dwarvish_chain_mail "Dwarvish chain mail"). Dwarvish chain mail grants 6 AC when worn and has a base material of iron, and grants a +1 AC bonus to dwarves that wear them, including player dwarves - when made of mithril, it behaves similarly to an improved dwarvish mithril-coat, and grants one more point of base AC and MC2.

### Hack'EM

In [Hack'EM](/wiki/Hack%27EM "Hack'EM"), dwarvish mithril-coats are replaced with dwarvish chain mail as in EvilHack.

## Encyclopedia entry

\_Mithril\_! All folk desired it. It could be beaten like  
copper, and polished like glass; and the Dwarves could make  
of it a metal, light and yet harder than tempered steel.  
Its beauty was like to that of common silver, but the beauty  
of \_mithril\_ did not tarnish or grow dim.

\[ The Fellowship of the Ring, by J.R.R. Tolkien ]
